definition: a word formed from another word or base : a word formed by derivation

examples: … the sonata form (itself a derivative of opera) …
the name "Mia" is a derivative of "Maria"

definition: the limit of the ratio of the change in a function to the corresponding change in its independent variable as the latter change approaches zero
a chemical substance related structurally to another substance and theoretically derivable from it
a substance that can be made from another substance
examples: Petroleum is a derivative of coal tar.

definition: a contract or security (see security sense 3) that derives its value from that of an underlying asset (such as another security) or from the value of a rate (as of interest or currency exchange) or index (see index entry 1 sense 1b) of asset value (such as a stock index)
formed from another word or base : formed by derivation
having parts that originate from another source : made up of or marked by derived elements

examples: a film using a derivative plot device
